author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Herbert Coward, Actor Who Played Toothless Man in ‘Deliverance,’ Dies at 85
description: The actor was killed in a motor vehicle accident in North Carolina, the authorities said.
content: Herbert Coward, the actor whose modest career included the small but memorable role of Toothless Man in the 1972 thriller “Deliverance,” was killed on Thursday in a motor vehicle accident in North Carolina. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Pet Dragons Linked to Rare Salmonella Strain in U.S. and Canada
description: Dozens of people, including babies, were sickened, according to a C.D.C. study that highlighted the risks of snuggling with the strikingly scaly lizards, many of which carry salmonella bacteria in their gut.
content: The outbreak of a rare strain of salmonella that sickened scores of people, including several infants, across the United States and Canada, has been linked to pet bearded dragons, some most likely obtained from the same breeder in Southeast Asia, according to a study published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: With ‘Masters of the Air,’ a 10-Year Dream Lifts Off
description: The Apple TV+ series from Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks is an heir to their World War II epic “Band of Brothers,” set this time among a group of bomber pilots.
content: After Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks spearheaded the epic 2001 World War II series “Band of Brothers,” Spielberg got some feedback from one of his most important critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: JetBlue Says It May Back Out of Deal to Acquire Spirit Airlines
description: Spirit said it saw “no basis” for termination. Just last week, both airlines said they intended to appeal a judge’s decision blocking the deal.
content: JetBlue Airways said on Friday that it might back out of a $3.8 billion acquisition of Spirit Airlines after a federal judge blocked the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: MoveOn Will Spend $32 Million to Back Biden and Other Democrats
description: The liberal group plans to pour cash into an effort to generate enthusiasm for the president and support Democratic Senate and House candidates.
content: The liberal activist group MoveOn will spend more than $32 million this year to back President Biden and Democratic candidates for the House and Senate, the organization’s leader said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: They Believed That God Had Brought Them Together
description: When the Rev. Peter Manning learned that Garth Wingfield had also completed the spiritual exercises of St. Ignatius, he thought, “Don’t screw this up.”
content: At first, the striking similarities in the Rev. Peter Manning and Garth Wingfield’s life paths made for fun first-date fodder. And then the parallels became too pronounced to chalk up to coincidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: How Donald Trump Divided Republicans on Immigration
description: Trump’s growing influence is dividing Republicans on an issue that once united the party.
content: Just as senators were closing in on a deal that Republican negotiators said would constitute the most conservative border security bill in decades, Donald Trump was closing in on the G.O.P. presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: After 25 Years of Practice, They Decided to Make It Legal
description: In 1998, Timothy Braun and Peter Arnold fell in love fast. Once gay marriage became legal, they were so busy raising daughters and building a life that they never got around to making it official.
content: Over this past Thanksgiving holiday, Timothy Craig Braun and Peter David Arnold broke the news to their 19-year-old fraternal twin daughters: After 25 years together, they were finally getting married.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Buried in Wegovy Costs, North Carolina Will Stop Paying for Obesity Drugs
description: Starting April 1, state employees in North Carolina will no longer have insurance coverage for costly weight-loss medications like Wegovy and Zepbound.
content: In June 2021, the insurance plan for North Carolina state employees was paying for 2,800 people to take weight-loss drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittani Samuel
title: ‘Zoomers’ Review: Just Don’t Kill the Vibes
description: Gen Z’s reputation for conflict avoidance, and the way digital media abets it, is a recurring theme in the latest by the “Dimes Square” playwright Matthew Gasda.
content: “Zoomers,” the new play written and directed by Matthew Gasda, explores the specific milieu of artsy 20-something transplants, largely the same population that frequents the Greenpoint loft of the Brooklyn Center for Theater Research, where the show is currently running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Republican-Appointed Judge Denounces Republican Distortions of Jan. 6
description: In a scathing statement, a Reagan appointee quoted statements about the riot that appeared to be from several Republican politicians and called them “preposterous.”
content: A Republican-appointed judge on Thursday denounced as “shameless” the attempts by prominent Republican politicians to recast the Jan. 6 riot in a positive light, including by portraying the Trump supporters who sacked Congress as having done nothing wrong and by calling those convicted of crimes political prisoners or hostages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Jon Franklin, Pioneering Apostle of Literary Journalism, Dies at 82
description: He won two Pulitzer Prizes by transforming accounts of doctors at work into in-depth, narrative articles that read like dramatic short stories.
content: Jon Franklin, an apostle of narrative short-story style journalism whose own work won the first Pulitzer Prizes awarded for feature writing and explanatory journalism, died on Sunday in Annapolis, Md. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Richard Prince to Pay Photographers Who Sued Over Copyright
description: Shortly before trial, Prince agreed to compensate two photographers whose images he had used in an installation.
content: The artist Richard Prince agreed to pay at least $650,000 to two photographers whose images he had incorporated in his own work, ending a long-running copyright dispute that had been closely monitored by the art world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Pennsylvania Governor Proposes to Overhaul the State University System
description: Gov. Josh Shapiro, declaring that the system is broken, plans to place most schools under the same system and lower tuition for low- and middle-income students.
content: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, who has complained that his state’s higher education “isn’t working,” proposed on Friday a sweeping overhaul of the state’s sprawling college and university system that would reduce tuition for many students and determine funding for individual schools based in part on their performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a French comedic swashbuckling adventure, Indian spy games and more.
content: Youssef (Nassim Lyes) is a habitual liar, a down-on-his-luck gambler and a hustler of fake luxury handbags. He is working these cons to impress his wealthy girlfriend — she thinks he has a regular office job. When Youssef reveals the truth, including his bald head underneath his wig, she leaves him. Soon Youssef has a new girlfriend, Stephanie (Zoé Marchal), a card shark with a crypto fortune. But his gambling catches up to him, and a few goons are sent to track him down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Photos That Capture the Soul of 1960s Dublin
description: Nearly six decades ago, a German-born photographer, Evelyn Hofer, created beautifully crafted shots of the city and its people.
content: For six months between 1965 and 1966, the German-born photographer Evelyn Hofer worked in Dublin, creating beautifully crafted portraits of the city and its people. Hofer took her time composing each shot, whether it captured a pair of housekeepers in brief repose or James Joyce’s death mask. The results were published in book form in 1967, to accompany an extended essay by V.S. Pritchett. Now, in DUBLIN (Steidl, $58), those images stand on their own to tell a thoughtful story of the city both in black-and-white and in quiet color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Iverson
title: The Worst Masterpiece: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ at 100
description: A jazz musician considers the legacy and unfulfilled promise of George Gershwin’s catchy — or you could say corny — repertory staple.
content: The work is a guaranteed success. After it is over, audience members leap out of their seats for a standing ovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: Economists Predicted a Recession. So Far They’ve Been Wrong.
description: A widely predicted recession never showed up. Now, economists are assessing what the unexpected resilience tells us about the future.
content: The recession America was expecting never showed up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Shaila Dewan and Anna Betts
title: ‘Textbook’ Execution or Botched One? Alabama Case Leaves Sides Divided.
description: Alabama officials said the nation’s first nitrogen gas execution was a model for other states. Critics called it appalling and far from what the state promised.
content: A day after Alabama became the first state to execute a prisoner with nitrogen gas, officials vowed on Friday to continue using the method in executions despite witnesses’ accounts that the prisoner writhed on the gurney for at least two minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Early Race for 2028
description: Keep an eye on Haley and DeSantis.
content: The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not quite over — notwithstanding what Donald Trump and many Republican leaders have asserted since Trump’s victory in New Hampshire on Tuesday. Nikki Haley is still running and attacking the former president as she moves around South Carolina, which will hold its Republican primary on Feb. 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: What to Know About Nevada’s Primary and Caucus
description: The presidential candidates may have turned their attention to South Carolina, but the next contests on the calendar are in the Silver State. The process there is complex and confusing.
content: As the calendar gets ready to flip to February and the remaining Republican presidential candidates move on from the early nominating states of Iowa and New Hampshire, it’s Nevada — not South Carolina — that’s next on the schedule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Liset Cruz and Kate Christobek
title: Wayne LaPierre, Longtime N.R.A. Chief, Testifies at Manhattan Trial
description: Mr. LaPierre, who is testifying in a civil corruption case, claimed to have no knowledge of the prodigious amounts the National Rifle Association was spending on chartered private jets.
content: With less than a week left as chief of the National Rifle Association, Wayne LaPierre got to look back at his 33-year tenure in a Manhattan courtroom on Friday, when he began testifying in a civil corruption case that the New York attorney general brought against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Godzilla Minus One’ Stomps Into ‘Oppenheimer’ Territory
description: Those movies, along with “The Boy and the Heron,” are essentially in conversation about the moral weight of American and Japanese actions in World War II.
content: I wasn’t expecting to cry as much as I did at “Godzilla Minus One.” The strong word-of-mouth made it sound like an awesome spectacle with cool action courtesy of the scaly title creature. And while there were awe-inducing showdowns with the monster, the Toho International production, written and directed by Takashi Yamazaki, is largely a meditation on sorrow and survival in the wake of World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Newspaper Deal Seen as a Fight for the Heart of the Tories
description: A bid by an Arab American group, fronted by Jeff Zucker, the former CNN president, to buy The Telegraph is under scrutiny. That might leave an opening for a right-wing investor.
content: The Daily Telegraph has long been viewed as the house paper of Britain's Conservative Party. So, it’s perhaps not surprising that a takeover battle for the 168-year-old paper has mutated into a political struggle within the Tory ranks — one that some commentators have gone so far as to cast as a contest for the party’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Alabama Hails Nitrogen Gas Execution, a New Attempt to Address an Old Challenge
description: Fending off doubts and criticisms, Alabama’s attorney general hailed a new execution method as “humane and effective.”
content: For as long as America has had the death penalty, there have been questions about how best to carry it out. The execution of Kenneth Eugene Smith in Alabama on Thursday, the first American execution in which death was caused by suffocation with nitrogen gas, gave no indication of settling the legal, moral and technical questions that have long bedeviled states as they mete out the ultimate punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: U.N. Court Declines to Order Cease-Fire, and Trump Takes the Stand
description: Plus, alarming Taylor Swift deepfakes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihoko Iida, Josh Robenstone and Richard Pedaline
title: The Dragon-Shaped Japanese Region Where Tokyo Locals Go to Unwind
description: A guide to Kagoshima, home to traditional pottery villages and the forest that inspired “Princess Mononoke.”
content: Kagoshima, the prefecture that wraps around the southern end of the Japanese island of Kyushu, is said by some to resemble the head of a dragon. At the mouth of this dragon stands Sakurajima, one of the country’s most active volcanoes, whose plumes of smoke can often be seen from the capital, Kagoshima City, just a short ferry ride away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Mutt,’ ‘Unpregnant’ and More Streaming Gems
description: The complexities of 21st-century romantic entanglements are front and center in this month’s roundup of hidden gems on your subscription streaming services.
content: Vuk Lungulov-Klotz’s micro-budget New York drama is everything indie movies are supposed to be: keenly observed and modestly executed, telling us a story and showing us a world we don’t usually see in mainstream cinema. In this case, it’s the world of Feña (Lío Mehiel), a transgender man and a semi-desperate pseudo-hustler whose life goes momentarily topsy-turvy when he accidentally reconnects with a former boyfriend from before his transition. Every performer is on point, natural and credible, and the screenplay is lived-in and mostly devoid of histrionics (Feña gives a big speech to his dad about how difficult it all is, and it’s the single false note, the only scene that feels like a scene from a movie instead of a scene from real life). This is a small film, but a mighty one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Jacobs
title: South Africa Sees Its Moral Conscience in a Genocide Case
description: For some South Africans, their nation’s charge of genocide against Israel evokes the ideals of the anti-apartheid struggle.
content: This month I went with my 18-year-old daughter to see the South African singer Thandiswa Mazwai perform with her band at a music festival in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart provide an endearing, confessional puzzle.
content: ACROSTIC — Solving this puzzle made me very nostalgic. It’s a passage by David Sedaris, a writer whom I discovered early in his career (via his 1994 book, “Barrel Fever”), before I myself settled into adulthood. He’s a meticulous memoirist, and I have learned so much about him over the years — from his youth spent in the oddest jobs to his current extravagant walking habit, which I envy and which will hopefully keep him alive forever. It’s almost as if we’ve grown up and old together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Austin Harper
title: The 100-Year Extinction Panic Is Back, Right on Schedule
description: The 100-Year Extinction Panic Is Back, Right on Schedule
content: “Do you think we’ll need to buy guns?” The student’s question seemed to drop the temperature in the room by several degrees. I was at a dinner with fellow academics, a few college students and a guest speaker who had just delivered an inspiring talk about climate justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Phones Track Everything but Their Role in Car Wrecks
description: Distracted driving is a worsening problem, safety experts say. Yet there is still no definitive database of the number of crashes or fatalities caused by it.
content: Cellphones can track what we say and write, where we go, what we buy and what we search on the internet. But they still aren’t being used to track one of the biggest public health threats: crashes caused by drivers distracted by the phones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: For the Most Groundbreaking Oscar Race This Year, Try Documentaries
description: All five nominees are international features focused on geopolitical events, and three are directed by women.
content: Most post-nomination Oscar chatter focuses on surprises and snubs connected to the fiction nominees. But I’m a nonfiction nerd, so for me the documentaries are where it’s at, and in recent years, the picks have grown delightfully unpredictable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: David J. Skal, Scholar Who Took Horror Seriously, Dies at 71
description: In books like “The Monster Show” and “Screams of Reason,” he examined the cultural significance of movies meant to scare the bejesus out of people.
content: David J. Skal, a witty historian of horror entertainment who found in movies like “Dracula” and “Rosemary’s Baby” both a mirror of evolving societal fears and a pressure-release valve for those anxieties, died on Jan. 1 in a car accident in Los Angeles. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Kardon and Jennifer Kavanagh
title: China Is Trying to Have It Both Ways in the Middle East
description: Beijing must share more of the burden of protecting sea lanes that are vital for its trade interests.
content: There has been plenty of hand-wringing in the West about the prospect of China displacing — or at least rivaling — the United States as the world’s leading superpower. But the evolving security crisis in the Red Sea makes clear that this remains a distant prospect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Frances Robles
title: Kenyan Court Blocks Deployment of Police Force to Haiti
description: A contingent of 1,000 Kenyan officers was intended to lead a multinational force financed by the United States to restore security in a Caribbean country terrorized by armed gangs.
content: A Kenyan court on Friday prohibited the deployment of 1,000 Kenyan police officers to Haiti, jeopardizing a multinational security force charged with stabilizing the chaos-hit Caribbean island nation before it even got off the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Worries in Europe Over the White House Move to Delay Gas Terminals
description: The Biden administration’s decision to review new liquefied natural gas projects for their impact on climate change could be a headache for overseas buyers.
content: The Biden administration’s decision to delay approval of new liquefied natural gas terminals in the United States has been hailed as a major victory for environmental advocacy groups, but it is creating unease outside the United States about future energy supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Suggest Events for Flashback, Our Weekly History Quiz
description: Every week, we test your knowledge. Now we want to tap your brainpower to compile events.
content: We invite New York Times readers to suggest events to be included in Flashback, our weekly history quiz. Our favorite events aren’t just matters of trivia — they include details that allow people to puzzle out the answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Handy
title: Picture Books About the Way We Look
description: A story of gross beauty from David Sedaris and Ian Falconer, a scabrous tale from Beatrice Alemagna, and more.
content: Who’s good-looking? Who’s not? Those are loaded questions that, these days, kid lit mostly avoids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Costumes of the Very, Very Rich
description: Forget quiet luxury. Maison Margiela, Fendi and Valentino offer some singular propositions.
content: The night of the wolf moon — the first full moon of the new year — also happened to be the last night of the couture, when John Galliano recreated a decaying Paris nightclub in the vaulted caverns beneath Paris’s Pont Alexandre III bridge across the Seine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: More Tenants Can Now Add Rent Payments to Their Credit Score
description: Policymakers view the reporting of an on-time pattern as a way to reduce disparities in homeownership.
content: About a third of American households rent, yet in most cases their credit score doesn’t reflect their on-time payments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Met Taps Endowment to Keep the Curtain Up
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 26, 2024.
content: “For most people the pandemic is over. For arts institutions, we’re still in it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: What to Know About the U.N. Aid Agency for Palestinians
description: Long a vital lifeline for Gazans, the agency known as UNRWA was a point of contention with Israel long before some of its workers were accused of taking part in the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel.
content: The U.N. agency that provides aid to Palestinians has been a vital lifeline in the Gaza Strip for generations — and it was a point of contention with Israel long before some of the agency’s employees were accused of involvement in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 assault on Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bergin
title: Indigenous Australians Plan to Go Bigger on Australia Day
description: “Invasion Day is the reason why we’re all here today, but we must go beyond that,” one activist said.
content: Parades, Union Jack themed barbecues, angry protests, and reflective vigils — it’s 2024, and Jan. 26 in Australia remains a day that inspires many different reactions across the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does ‘Barbie’ Deserve All the Hype?
description: Pamela Paul thinks not. Our letter writers are split. Also: Donald Trump’s opposition to a border deal in Congress; an Israel-Hamas cease-fire?
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Biden Administration Faces Pushback on Another Gas Project, This Time Overseas
description: After the recent decision to pause the approval process on a giant new export terminal in Louisiana, activists are hoping to stop American money from supporting a project in Papua New Guinea.
content: Even as the Biden administration, under pressure from environmentalists, hits pause on its approval of a major natural gas export terminal in the United States, it faces another big gas decision overseas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: In Angola, a Former Cold War Rival, Blinken Touts U.S. Investments
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken finished a four-nation tour of Africa with a visit to Angola, site of major new U.S. investments, which may help counter China’s influence.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken wrapped up a four-nation tour through Africa on Thursday with a visit to Angola, an oil-rich former Cold War battleground that has become the site of a struggle for 21st-century economic influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: At Sundance, a Transcendent Road Trip and Other Reasons to Love Movies
description: A documentary about Will Ferrell and his friend Harper Steele brought the house down. It was just one of several discoveries at this year’s festival.
content: On Tuesday, after days of tramping around Park City, Utah, griping about the movies and the logistical headaches this mountain resort town presents, I was transported into the Sundance Film Festival that I always hope for, the one in which a movie surprises and moves and maybe delights me, and so successfully makes good on its promise that, after the lights come up, the crowd delivers the festival version of hallelujah with a floor-shaking standing ovation. I admit, I wasn’t expecting that to happen when I walked into the new Will Ferrell joint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Genocide Ruling Has Deep Symbolism but Little Immediate Effect
description: The decision by the World Court did not order Israel to cease its war against Hamas in Gaza. But the court made a move imbued with historical meaning.
content: A ruling on Friday by the International Court of Justice on charges of genocide against Israel had deep historical resonance for both Israelis and Palestinians. But it lacked immediate practical consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Pauses Approvals of New Gas Export Terminals
description: The president said the government would analyze impacts on climate, the economy and national security before approving new projects.
content: President Biden on Friday paused the permitting process for new liquefied natural gas export facilities in order to analyze their impact on climate change, the economy and national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Cupcake A.T.M.s and Fire Pits: What You Love at the Airport
description: We asked readers to share their favorite airport amenities. The answers: everything from a library to a swimming pool. Here’s a selection of delights, open to all, from airports around the globe.
content: For many travelers, airports are places to pass through as swiftly as possible, not places to savor. The incessant drone of announcements, the frustration of being shut out of increasingly exclusive lounges, the overpriced food, the serpentine lines and the fruitless search for an electrical outlet all can make for a hellish experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Nikki Haley and the W-Word
description: Haley doesn’t talk very much about her gender, even though it excites some voters.
content: Back in 2012, long before Nikki Haley hit the presidential campaign trail — and years before Hillary Clinton faced off against Donald Trump — Ms. Haley, then the governor of South Carolina, told this newspaper, “The reason I actually ran for office is because of Hillary Clinton.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Once Upon a Mattress’ Review: Sutton Foster as a Perfectly Goofy Princess
description: The Encores! series returns with a concert staging of the 1959 musical, which also stars the very funny Harriet Harris and Michael Urie.
content: Some casting choices are blindingly obvious. That does not make them lazy; it makes them right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, Jonah E. Bromwich, Maria Cramer and Kate Christobek
title: Jury Orders Trump to Pay Carroll $83.3 Million After Years of Insults
description: The ex-president was found liable for sexually abusing E. Jean Carroll, but called her a liar. The award was “a huge defeat for every bully who has tried to keep a woman down,” she said.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump was ordered by a Manhattan jury on Friday to pay $83.3 million to the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her in 2019 after she accused him of a decades-old rape, attacks he continued in social media posts, at news conferences and even in the midst of the trial itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: To Fix Its Airlines, Does the U.S. Need to Rethink Regulation?
description: Deregulation has succeeded in some ways, but consumer dissatisfaction abounds.
content: I was a senior in college in 1978 when I wrote my first opinion piece that touched on airline deregulation. It was an editorial in The Cornell Daily Sun (“Ithaca’s only morning newspaper”!) titled “Our Man in Washington,” and it was about Alfred Kahn, a colorful Cornell economist who presided over deregulation of airlines at the Civil Aeronautics Board from 1977 to 1978 before becoming President Jimmy Carter’s inflation czar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Zachary Small
title: Leading Museums Remove Native Displays Amid New Federal Rules
description: The American Museum of Natural History is closing two major halls as museums around the nation respond to updated policies from the Biden administration.
content: The American Museum of Natural History will close two major halls exhibiting Native American objects, its leaders said on Friday, in a dramatic response to new federal regulations that require museums to obtain consent from tribes before displaying or performing research on cultural items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdullah Zahid
title: The Cost of the American Dream? Our Intimacy.
description: A physical relationship is nearly impossible for a hard-working Bangladeshi taxi driver and his wife, who longed for each other.
content: Certain mornings can seem exceptionally beautiful for no apparent reason. One morning many years ago, 18 months after my wife and I had moved to New York City from Dhaka, Bangladesh, my heart felt light. The sun had risen brilliantly, dispelling the gloom that had clouded the skies for days. Maybe I was feeling good because of this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 26, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about Republicans in Congress who are now endorsing Donald Trump after his New Hampshire primary win misquoted Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota. He stated he has always said he would “support” the eventual Republican Party presidential nominee, not that he would “endorse” the nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The meaning of the first I.C.J. ruling in the genocide case against Israel
description: And why alliances will determine what comes next.
content: Today the United Nations’ highest court, the International Court of Justice, issued its first, preliminary decision in the genocide case South Africa brought against Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Best Part of Tiny Living? The ‘Freedom We Have Created for Ourselves.’
description: With a little house in The Hague, a compact getaway on the Italian island of Sardinia and a well-designed camper van, who needs a conventional home?
content: Who says you have to live in one place? Maybe a few tiny homes would be preferable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Malia Obama at Sundance: A Fledgling Filmmaker Makes Her Debut
description: The former first daughter’s short, “The Heart,” focuses on a sensitive man racked with guilt when his mother dies after they have an argument.
content: If you’re a celebrity seeking to rebrand, the Sundance Film Festival can offer a useful assist. From Marvel superheroes seeking an indie turn to teenage movie stars hoping to segue into spicy adult roles, the snowy event is the perfect place to debut a new direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘The Door’s Open!’
description: Sarah Sinclair and Rafael Musa invite us in.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Bernstein
title: After a Boom, Craft Beer Considers a New Creed: Less Is More
description: Many breweries, bars and supermarkets that once offered a dizzying array of new beers are now paring back to a chosen few.
content: More than a decade ago, when Ryan Guererri was in his early 20s, he became obsessed with craft beer. As breweries rolled out a nonstop roster of new products, he bought hundreds of different beers, from bitter I.P.A.s to strong Belgian ales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Are You a Fan of Movie Remakes?
description: Can they be just as good, or even better, than the originals?
content: Have you seen any movies lately? When you choose what to watch, are you more likely to go for something new and original, or rather a remake of an old favorite?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Calista Flockhart Is Back, With a Flock of Venomous Swans
description: The “Ally McBeal” star takes on the darker, dagger-like role of Lee Radziwill in “Feud.”
content: On a chilly January weekend in Los Angeles, I turned into a truffle pig. I foraged relentlessly all over town, looking for truffle fries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Biden Vows Border Shutdown, Pressing Congress to Pass Immigration Deal
description: The president’s statement came as the Republican speaker of the House pronounced the emerging bipartisan immigration deal “dead on arrival” in his chamber.
content: President Biden fought on Friday to save a bipartisan immigration deal from collapse in Congress, vowing to shut down the border if the plan became law even as the Republican speaker pronounced it dead on arrival in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: More Atmospheric Rivers Are on the Way. Here’s What the West Can Expect.
description: A sequence of atmospheric rivers will bring heavy rainfall and snow to the Western U.S. and Canada over the next week.
content: The Western United States and Canada are likely to see excessive rain and heavy snowfall from a sequence of back-to-back atmospheric rivers beginning this weekend and continuing into next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Mocks Trump’s Three-Minute Testimony
description: “We’re smack-dab in the heart of primary season, and Donald Trump is out there trying to win over the voters that matter most: his juries,” Stephen Colbert said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: They Fell in Love After She ‘Bamboozled’ Him.
description: During the coronavirus lockdown, Joseph Caneco and Layne Hilton were both willing to step outside their comfort zones, if not their homes.
content: Joseph Anthony Caneco waited a week to respond to Layne Clark Hilton when she messaged him on Tinder in May 2020 — not because he was playing games, but because he was in a semi-crisis. He had to keep bringing Beanhead, his beloved cat, back to the emergency room. “I had my hands full,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Kate LoPresti, Jen Poyant, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: Mediapocalypse Now, a16z’s Chris Dixon Defends Crypto, and HatGPT
description: Strangely a lot of pro wrestling in this episode.
content: Layoffs are hitting newsrooms and publishers again, as tech platforms, ad markets and artificial intelligence reshape the internet. Kevin Roose and Casey Newton have ideas for solutions. Then, one of the most influential investors in crypto companies lays out where the industry went wrong, and why he still thinks blockchains are the future. And finally, a round of HatGPT with the week’s tech headlines, including a spicy LinkedIn post and an A.I. test that disturbs Kevin and Casey’s sense of reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Cuomo Created ‘Sexually Hostile’ Workplace, Says Justice Department
description: Investigators found that the executive staff of Andrew Cuomo, the former governor, prioritized protecting him rather than the women accusing him of sexual harassment.
content: The Department of Justice concluded that former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and his executive staff subjected female employees to a “sexually hostile work environment,” and then retaliated against several who complained, according to a settlement announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Can A.I. Help the Fire Trucks Show Up Sooner?
description: A research project aims to gather street-level data that can be used to help emergency responders avoid getting stuck in traffic.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how an artificial intelligence project could help the Fire Department cut response times for firefighters and ambulances. We’ll also look at Donald Trump’s brief testimony at his defamation trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Palestinian Americans’ Lawsuit in Oakland Seeks to Halt U.S. Support for Israel
description: The case, filed in Federal District Court in Northern California, is unlikely to succeed, given legal precedents regarding foreign policy decisions. But it has energized pro-Palestinian activists.
content: Palestinian American plaintiffs asked a federal judge in California on Friday to force the White House to withdraw U.S. support for Israel pending a cease-fire in Gaza and accused President Biden and other administration officials of abetting a genocide of the Palestinian people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Blumenthal
title: One Hope From Changes at This Holocaust Museum: Fewer Nazi Selfies
description: A redesign at the Zekelman Holocaust Center near Detroit provides less opportunity to pose in front of Nazi images as it attempts to refocus attention on the victims, not the perpetrators.
content: Students on school trips to a Holocaust museum outside Detroit would stand riveted at one stark display: a Nazi officer’s black uniform with a red swastika armband, guns and a whip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Boebert Is Target of Rivals at Debate for New-to-Her District
description: Seeking a better shot at victory, and after the “Beetlejuice” incident, Lauren Boebert is shifting districts for her 2024 run. Her fellow Republicans onstage reminded her of it repeatedly.
content: Representative Lauren Boebert, the far-right firebrand, faced off against eight Republican opponents on Thursday night in a debate in the new Colorado district she is seeking to represent in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: George Carlin’s Estate Sues Podcasters Over A.I. Episode
description: The lawsuit claims that an hourlong comedy special on YouTube violated Carlin’s copyright.
content: The estate of the comedian George Carlin sued the makers of a podcast on Thursday after they claimed to use artificial intelligence to impersonate Carlin for a comedy special.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and Isayen Herrera
title: Venezuela’s Highest Court Bars Opposition Leader From Running for President
description: The move is a crippling blow to a deal in which President Nicolás Maduro’s administration promised a free and fair election in exchange for relief from U.S. sanctions.
content: Venezuela’s highest court ruled on Friday that a top opposition leader cannot run for president, dealing a crippling blow to prospects for credible elections that the government had agreed to hold this year in exchange for the lifting of crippling U.S. economic sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: atavistic
description: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word atavistic has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 21 in “The Robots Can’t Take Taxi-Whistling Away From Me” by Jon Gluck:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: What Do You Call a Galaxy Without Stars?
description: To dark matter and dark energy, add dark galaxies — collections of stars so sparse and faint that they are all but invisible.
content: What do you call a galaxy without stars?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: One of 2 Inmates Who Escaped Arkansas Jail Is Caught
description: Noah Roush, 22, was captured Thursday after he and another detainee escaped from a jail in Pine Bluff this week. The other escapee, a murder suspect, remains at large.
content: One of two men who escaped from an Arkansas jail this week has been captured, the authorities said, after officials received a tip that he was hiding out in an abandoned home. The other escapee, a murder suspect, was still at large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Charles Admitted to U.K. Hospital for Prostate Procedure
description: Buckingham Palace said the king was being treated at a London hospital. Catherine, Princess of Wales, remains hospitalized after abdominal surgery last week.
content: King Charles III has been admitted to a London hospital for a procedure to treat an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace confirmed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Your Favorite Roadside Attractions
description: It’s been delightful reading your emails about favorite stops, and seeing the state’s highways and landmarks through your eyes.
content: Driving to Davis from the Bay Area on Interstate 80 last week, I spotted a cow jumping over the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jo-El Sonnier, Who Sparked a Revival of Cajun Music, Dies at 77
description: An accordion virtuoso and a gifted vocalist, he scored country hits in the 1980s by putting a Cajun spin on songs like Richard Thompson’s “Tear-Stained Letter.”
content: Jo-El Sonnier, a singer and accordionist who revived Cajun music in popular culture with hit versions of Richard Thompson’s “Tear-Stained Letter” and Slim Harpo’s “Rainin’ in My Heart,” and with appearances on recordings by Mark Knopfler and Elvis Costello, died on Jan. 13 after a performance in Llano, Texas. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Audiobook of the Week: Leslie Jones Riffs in the Recording Studio
description: The comedian goes off-script while revisiting her raw and hilarious memoir, “Leslie F*cking Jones.”
content: Leslie Jones has been a comedian for decades, but listening to her read her memoir, “Leslie F*cking Jones,” you get the impression that she still has all the vigor of someone only getting started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Could Israel Cost Biden the Election?
description: The hosts unpack the truism that voters don’t care about foreign policy.
content: It’s an old truism that Americans don’t care about foreign policy when it’s time to cast their ballots. But with the crisis in Gaza, a prolonged conflict in Ukraine and a trade war brewing with China, could 2024 be the year that American voters finally care about what’s going on beyond the water’s edge?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: Trump Walks Out of Courtroom During Closing Arguments by Carroll’s Lawyer
description: The lawyer for E. Jean Carroll began by focusing her presentation on the harm Mr. Trump inflicted on her client. Soon after, he stood up and walked out.
content: Donald J. Trump did not stay to hear closing arguments on Friday from the lawyer representing the woman who sued him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: The Enduring Appeal of Britain’s Posh Young Things
description: For 13 years, the reality show “Made in Chelsea” has taken viewers inside the wealthy London borough. Soon, an Australian spinoff will test if it works elsewhere.
content: In late 2010, on the verge of signing a contract to appear on a new reality TV series about fashionable young people in one of London’s wealthiest boroughs, Ollie Locke, then 23, had a moment of hesitation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: These Are Superior Potatoes
description: You’d expect a Kenji López-Alt recipe for roasted potatoes to produce scientifically proven, unfailingly crispy potatoes. You’d be right.
content: Good morning. Mark Bittman is a freewheeling cook, a minimalist, open to improvisation. His recipes are often set-it-and-forget-it in style. If I were writing his biography, I’d title it “Largely Unattended.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Jürgen Klopp Dragged Liverpool Into the Future. Now He’ll Let It Go.
description: A trophy-winning manager’s announcement that he will step down at the end of the season is a chance to take the measure of success.
content: For Jürgen Klopp, the montages will be long and they will be emotional. There will, naturally, be artful drone shots of Liverpool’s skyline. There will be slow-motion footage of red-and-white scarves, twirling and writhing. There will, absolutely, be a stirring, possibly classical score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Marc Jaffe, Publisher of Paperback Hits, Is Dead at 102
description: He oversaw a boom in the format beginning in the 1960s, turning out best-sellers like “Jaws,” “The Exorcist” and “The Catcher in the Rye.”
content: Marc Jaffe was at a New Year’s Eve party of Hollywood types in 1967 when a screenwriter named William Peter Blatty began chatting him up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: A Key Inflation Measure Cooled in December
description: Inflation has been slowing swiftly, and fresh data showed that a core price gauge fell below 3 percent for the first time in years last month.
content: A measure of inflation closely watched by the Federal Reserve continued to cool in December, the latest sign that price increases are coming back under control even as growth remains solid and the labor market healthy. In particularly positive news, a key gauge of price increases dipped below 3 percent for the first time since early 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Will Be Able to Wait to Pay Full $83.3 Million Until All Appeals Are Exhausted
description: Donald J. Trump — the rare defendant who can afford a judgment of this size — could secure a bond to cover it while his appeals play out.
content: Donald J. Trump might one day have to pay E. Jean Carroll the $83.3 million she was awarded, but that day is not today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The F.T.C. Takes on A.I. Deals
description: The agency is concerned that transactions including Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI could hinder competition and innovation.
content: Tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon and Google have sought an edge in the artificial intelligence race by investing in innovative start-ups like OpenAI and Anthropic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Happily Married, and Seeing Other People
description: The author Molly Roden Winter discusses her new memoir, “More,” about her and her husband’s decision to have an open marriage.
content: Molly Roden Winter and her husband, Stewart, have been married for 24 years. But since 2008, by mutual agreement, they have also dated other people — an arrangement that Winter explains in sometimes granular detail in her new memoir, “More: A Memoir of Open Marriage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Kim Kardashian Cozies Up to Balenciaga
description: And so does Patricia Field. Plus, Zac Posen creates high-society costumes, a tutu sells for $52,000 and a fashion curator gets knighted.
content: Is anyone still rocked by Balenciaga’s notorious ad campaign from 2022 featuring teddy bears in harnesses? Seemingly not Kim Kardashian, who was “re-evaluating” her relationship with the fashion house in the wake of the scandal those ads caused, only to be named an ambassador for the brand this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauretta Charlton
title: A Fond Farewell to South Korea
description: An editor recalls moving to Seoul during the coronavirus pandemic and watching The Times open a digital newsroom in the city.
content: There was no telling what I would find when I arrived in Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Email Misfire Adds Drama to the War for a New York Casino License
description: An errant email has led to collusion accusations and subpoenas, illustrating the cutthroat environment surrounding the battle for a casino license in New York.
content: In the billionaire-versus-billionaire contest to open a casino in the United States’ last, great untapped gambling market, an errant email can become a dangerous weapon in an opponent’s hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: Modern train heists. Also, ghostwriters emerge from the shadows and why Gen Z believes its “aging like milk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: A New Way to Hear The Amplifier (Plus 5 More Whistling Songs)
description: Listen to a deluxe edition of the playlist, including an addition from noted whistler Andrew Bird, now available on Apple Music.
content: Since we started The Amplifier — gasp — almost a year ago now, there is one question I’ve been asked over and over (and over): “When are you going to start putting your playlists on Apple Music?” If you are one of those many people who inquired, I have great news: That day has finally arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: Former W.W.E. Employee Accuses Vince McMahon of Sex Trafficking
description: In a lawsuit, the woman says Mr. McMahon hired her at the pro wrestling company in exchange for sex and then abused her for years.
content: A former employee of World Wrestling Entertainment sued Vince McMahon, the longtime chairman and chief executive of W.W.E., in federal court on Thursday, accusing him of physical and emotional abuse, sexual assault and trafficking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Bettina Was Much More Than an Eccentric of the Chelsea Hotel
description: A gallery in New York’s Chinatown has brought downtown buzz to an enigmatic artist, two years after her death.
content: One night in November, a procession of young artists, critics and curators climbed the creaky stairs of a building in Chinatown in Lower Manhattan to attend an opening at a buzzy little gallery, Ulrik. The show, “Bettina: New York 1965–86,” was made up of rarely seen photographs and sculptures by an enigmatic artist who lived for five decades at the fabled Chelsea Hotel, where she created her works in a cluttered fifth-floor apartment until her death in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Victims Describe Their Pain and Prisoners Apologize in Bali Bombing Trial
description: A Guantánamo military court heard anguishing testimony at the sentencing hearing for two Malaysian prisoners who pleaded guilty after 20 years of detention.
content: Relatives of tourists killed in the 2002 terrorist bombing in Bali, Indonesia, spoke of endless, devastating grief, and two prisoners who conspired in the attack renounced violence in the name of Islam on Thursday for a U.S. military jury assembled at Guantánamo Bay to deliberate their sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Truman Capote Cashed In on His Friends’ Secrets. It Cost Him Everything.
description: The rarefied social circle that embraced Capote, and eventually banished him, is up for re-evaluation in the new television series “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans.”
content: In 1979, five years before he died and four years after his exile from the Upper East Side’s social cockpit, Truman Capote appeared on a talk show as a friend of the common man. The host, David Susskind, remained unpersuaded. “You are always on people’s yachts” and in “great mansions on Long Island,” he pointed out. “The thing in Spain with the Pamplona bull runs.” Come on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Voters in Colorado Case Lay Out Their Argument to Block Trump From Ballot
description: A group of Colorado voters urged the Supreme Court to uphold a lower court decision blocking the former president from the state’s primary ballot.
content: A group of Colorado voters laid out its argument to the Supreme Court on Friday for why former President Donald J. Trump should be barred from the state’s primary ballot, contending that his actions leading up to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol amounted to an insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Noble Maillard
title: The Most Foolproof Way to Cook Fish? The Microwave.
description: This appliance can turn out perfectly cooked salmon in less than 10 minutes.
content: Gary Weinstein, a retired lawyer, has lived in Manhattan for 30 years, and for most of that time, he has used his oven for storage. “It stares at me with mockery,” he said, gesturing to the forsaken pans inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Extends American Journalist’s Detention
description: The ruling means that Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, will spend at least a year in custody awaiting trial on a spying charge Washington says is politically motivated.
content: A court in Moscow on Friday extended the pretrial detention of an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who is awaiting a hearing on an espionage charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government vehemently deny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Wrong Party May Be Worrying About Its Nominee
description: Trump is assured of nothing.
content: Technically speaking, Donald Trump is still far from winning the Republican presidential nomination, but his victory on Tuesday in the New Hampshire primary was enough to push the Republican National Committee off the sidelines and into his corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Ken Belson
title: Will Fanatics Upend the World of Sports Collectibles?
description: Powered by its connections with leagues and star athletes, the merchandising giant has entered the hobby universe with deep pockets and sharp elbows. Not everyone is happy.
content: On the Saturday before Thanksgiving, thousands of people filed into a dated convention center near O’Hare Airport to participate in the very American pastime of buying and selling sports trading cards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Jamie Dimon Reshuffles Management Team at JPMorgan Chase
description: Many consider the moves a sign of a succession plan at the nation’s largest bank, although the stalwart Mr. Dimon has signaled he is not going anywhere.
content: JPMorgan Chase is reshuffling its leadership team, a move that many consider a succession plan even though its longtime chief executive, Jamie Dimon, has signaled he is staying put.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: What Do A.A., Burning Man and the Talmud Have in Common? This Guy.
description: In “Subculture Vulture,” the comedian Moshe Kasher explores the six wildly differing communities that made him who he is, for better or worse.
content: About three-quarters of the way through his new memoir, “Subculture Vulture,” the writer and comedian Moshe Kasher warns that, right about now, readers might want to bail and head to YouTube: He’s about to explain the Talmud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: The uncertain future for Gaza.
content: What could happen to Gaza in the aftermath of Israel’s war? A clear line between war and peace in Gaza is deeply implausible, with Israeli forces likely to come in and out of the territory for a long time, and the future is murky at best, Steven Erlanger, our chief diplomatic correspondent, writes in an analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Justin Timberlake’s Envious Comeback, and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear new music from Marc Anthony, Ice Spice and Hiatus Kaiyote.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Gen Z Is Listening to What Netanyahu Is Saying. Is Biden?
description: Israel is losing the support of a generation, not just a few student groups. And it is losing it because of what it does, not what it is.
content: “My insistence is what has prevented — over the years — the establishment of a Palestinian state that would have constituted an existential danger to Israel,” Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday. “As long as I am prime minister, I will continue to strongly insist on this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Trump Ordered to Pay Carroll $83.3 Million
description: Also, a U.N. court ordered Israel to prevent genocide.
content: A federal jury in Manhattan ordered former President Donald Trump to pay $83.3 million to the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her in social media posts, news conferences and on the campaign trail ever since she first accused him in 2019 of raping her in a department store dressing room decades earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
title: France Tries to Contain Protests by Farmers as Outrage Spreads
description: The government announced measures to quell the anger, including the scrapping of a fuel tax increase, as thousands of tractors blocked highways across the country.
content: Protests by farmers angered by complex regulations, administrative hassles and low wages spread across France on Friday, blocking several highways, snarling traffic for miles and forcing the country’s new prime minister to tear up his schedule and head to a remote farm in the region where the demonstrations began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Leaders Slam U.N. Court Ruling but Applaud Lack of Cease-fire Order
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the genocide charge against Israel “outrageous,” but said the U.N. court had upheld the country’s right of self-defense.
content: Officials in Israel on Friday denounced the International Court of Justice’s order seeking to prevent genocidal acts in its offensive against Hamas in Gaza but also expressed relief the court did not order it to halt its military campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Suspiro a la Limeña, a Peruvian Dessert to Leave You Thunderstruck
description: It’s easy to fall for this caramelized custard with a dollop of meringue and a name that evokes a sigh of love.
content: The origin story of one of Peru’s most popular desserts is almost as romantic as its name — suspiro a la limeña, or “the sigh of a lady from Lima.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo, Emily Schmall and Remy Tumin
title: 23andMe Breach Targeted Jewish and Chinese Customers, Lawsuit Says
description: The class-action suit said the genetic testing company failed to notify customers whose personal information was compiled into “curated” lists that were sold on the dark web.
content: The genetic testing company 23andMe is being accused in a class-action lawsuit of failing to protect the privacy of customers whose personal information was exposed last year in a data breach that affected nearly seven million profiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Takes Messaging Crackdown to Customers’ Macs
description: Beeper Mini customers were using their Mac computers to connect to iPhone messaging on their Android phones. Now, they say Apple has blocked the messaging service on their Macs.
content: When Apple blocked the Beeper Mini app last month from giving Android users access to the tech giant’s messaging service, Beeper encouraged customers to use their Mac computers instead to connect and continue sending messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Jesse Jane, Pornographic Film Star, Dies at 43
description: Ms. Jane starred in the highest-budget film series in pornographic film history.
content: Jesse Jane, a onetime Hooters waitress and beauty pageant contestant who went on to star in the highest-budget film series in pornographic film history, was found dead on Wednesday at a home in Oklahoma. She was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Hot-Air Balloon
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and John Yoon
title: Explicit Deepfake Images of Taylor Swift Elude Safeguards and Swamp Social Media
description: Fans of the star and lawmakers condemned the images, probably generated by artificial intelligence, after they were shared with millions of social media users.
content: Fake, sexually explicit images of Taylor Swift likely generated by artificial intelligence spread rapidly across social media platforms this week, disturbing fans who saw them and reigniting calls from lawmakers to protect women and crack down on the platforms and technology that spread such images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Why Nikki Haley Has So Few Friends Left in South Carolina Politics
description: Nikki Haley could use some help rescuing her campaign. But Republicans in her home state are flocking to Donald J. Trump.
content: The stories pile up one after another, of thanks not offered, allies antagonized, opponents not forgiven — a portrait of a politician who climbed the ladder with speed and skill but failed to ensure that the people who helped her would have her back if she needed them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Bidencare Is a Really Big Deal
description: Health coverage is one area where a president’s policy makes all the difference.
content: In 2010, at the signing of the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare, Joe Biden, the vice president at the time, was caught on a hot mic telling President Barack Obama that the bill was a “big deal.” OK, there was actually another word in the middle. Anyway, Biden was right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Tina Antolini, Dan Powell, Diane Wong and Jon Pareles
title: New Music for Your Weekend
description: From a stadium-size stomp to the most intimate private reflection.
content: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic, picks his favorite new tracks to listen to this weekend:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: How to Save a Sad, Lonely, Angry and Mean Society
description: Consuming culture gives us the emotional knowledge that can make us better people.
content: Recently, while browsing in the Museum of Modern Art store in New York, I came across a tote bag with the inscription, “You are no longer the same after experiencing art.” It’s a nice sentiment, I thought, but is it true? Or to be more specific: Does consuming art, music, literature and the rest of what we call culture make you a better person?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Haley Assails Trump as ‘Unhinged’ and Dismisses Calls to Exit the Race
description: Nikki Haley attacked the Republican front-runner during an appearance Friday on Fox News.
content: Nikki Haley on Friday called Donald J. Trump “totally unhinged” after a failed attempt by one of his allies to push the Republican National Committee to declare him the party’s presumptive nominee, escalating her attacks on his mental acuity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: After Divorcing, They Turned to Each Other. Again.
description: After Pamela Dillon and Stephen Dillon split in 2008, they became business partners. Over a decade later, they realized they were still in love.
content: After a brief introduction at La Terrasse, a bar on the University of Pennsylvania’s campus that has since closed, on Sept. 29, 1983, Pamela Ann Dillon spent the next few hours hanging on to Stephen Michael Dillon’s every word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: You Saw Jason Kelce. This Guy Saw ‘The Feast of Bacchus.’
description: With his Art But Make It Sports social media accounts, LJ Rader connects the drama and pathos of classic artwork to viral moments in sports. And no, he’s not using A.I.
content: LJ Rader tries to be online as much as possible during big sporting events, but he missed the first half of last Sunday’s N.F.L. playoff game between the Buffalo Bills and the Kansas City Chiefs because of a dinner engagement. After he left the restaurant, Mr. Rader checked his phone and saw an unusual request: The N.F.L. had tagged him on X, formerly known as Twitter, hoping he would deliver one of his signature creations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Edward Wong, Russell Goldman and Ronen Bergman
title: U.N. to Investigate Claim That Employees Participated in Oct. 7 Attack
description: The United States temporarily cut off funding to UNRWA, the agency that aids Palestinians, citing allegations that 12 of its workers were involved in the Hamas-led assault on southern Israel.
content: The United Nations on Friday fired 12 of its employees in Gaza and began an investigation into them after accusations by Israel that they had helped plan and had participated in the Oct. 7 terrorist assault that left about 1,200 Israelis dead and more than 240 others captured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: A Child of Another War Who Makes Music for Ukrainians
description: Mirza Ramic, a Bosnian who sought refuge in the United States, is bringing his electronic music to Ukraine, “to show my support in these hard times.”
content: When the owner of an underground club in Kyiv reached out to Western musicians to play in Ukraine, long before the war, there were not so many takers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘In the Summers,’ a Father-Daughters Tale, Wins the Top Prize at Sundance
description: The jury focused largely on under-the-radar titles, though a Jesse Eisenberg-Kieran Culkin collaboration also was recognized.
content: “In the Summers,” an independent film about two sisters navigating fraught summer visits with their father, won the top prize in the Sundance Film Festival’s U.S. dramatic competition on Friday. The movie also won the competition’s directing award for its first-time filmmaker, Alessandra Lacorazza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Midlife Doesn’t Have to Be a Crisis
description: We asked experts for tips on savoring and celebrating this phase of life.
content: My teenage daughter recently asked me what my favorite decade has been so far. “This one,” I told her. “My 50s.” She stared at me in disbelief. “But you’re middle-aged,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Katie Engelhart, Luke Vander Ploeg, Clare Toeniskoetter, Diana Nguyen, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Mother Who Changed: A Story of Dementia
description: When cognitive decline changes people, should we respect their new desires?
content: Across the United States, millions of families are confronting a seemingly impossible question: When dementia changes a relative, how much should they accommodate their new personality and desires?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Is Cryptocurrency Like Stocks and Bonds? Courts Move Closer to an Answer.
description: Federal judges are weighing whether digital currencies should be subject to the same rules as stocks and bonds. The outcome could shape crypto’s future in the U.S.
content: For more than a decade, the pioneers of the cryptocurrency industry envisioned digital coins as an alternate branch of finance, a renegade sector that would operate outside the reach of big banks and government regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: 2 Powerful Restaurant Groups Team Up to Make Marea a Global Brand
description: Major Food Group, the team behind Carbone, plans to help Altamarea Group open Marea satellites around the world.
content: Marea, the plush Italian seafood restaurant on Central Park South, reopened last fall with subtle renovations to repair flood damage. Now the restaurant is embarking on a bigger change, joining another of New York’s premier restaurant groups to expand what it calls “the Marea brand” worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: David L. Mills, Who Kept the Internet Running on Time, Dies at 85
description: He developed and implemented the protocol that synchronizes the digital clocks nestled within billions of networked devices.
content: David L. Mills, an internet pioneer who developed and, for decades, implemented the timekeeping protocol used by financial markets, power grids, satellites and billions of computers to make sure they run simultaneously, earning him a reputation as the internet’s “Father Time,” died on Jan. 17 at his home in Newark, Del. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: My Sister and I Didn’t Speak for Decades. Could a Baby Change That?
description: Estrangement felt like a hole that was impossible to fill. The birth of my daughter provided the impetus to try.
content: The woman in the vegan diner mentioned her thumbs. They looked like they had been hammered flat, just like mine. I felt the rush of connection, followed by the ache of regret. This woman, my sister, was a stranger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Yes, Take Me Back to 2001
description: Toward a constructive politics of nostalgia.
content: In 1996, accepting the Republican nomination for president, an aged (by his era’s standards, not ours) Bob Dole issued a stirring defense of the past against the present. “Let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth,” he told his audience. “Let me be the bridge to a time of tranquillity, faith and confidence in action. And to those who say it was never so, that America’s not been better, I say you’re wrong. And I know because I was there. And I have seen it. And I remember.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Alexandra Stevenson
title: As China’s Markets Stumble, Japan Rises Toward Record
description: A change in perception among investors about China and Japan is one of the biggest themes in the markets right now.
content: There’s a shift underway in Asia that’s reverberating through global financial markets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times Quiz, Jan. 26, 2024
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, January 27, 2024
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: Luxury Fireplaces Are Keeping New Yorkers Warm This Winter
description: Once a necessity, fireplaces are now an indulgence in New York City.
content: Once a necessity, fireplaces are now an indulgence in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The presidential campaign was top of mind for the hosts, who discussed Gov. Ron DeSantis bowing out and Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary over Nikki Haley.
content: The presidential campaign was top of mind for the hosts, who discussed Gov. Ron DeSantis bowing out and Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary over Nikki Haley.

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by V.V. Ganeshananthan, John Hendrickson, De’Shawn Charles Winslow and more.
content: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by V.V. Ganeshananthan, John Hendrickson, De’Shawn Charles Winslow and more.

title: ‘Dry-Clean Only’? Not Necessarily.
description: Forget what the label says.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the new comedy from Mike Judge and Zach Woods, “In the Know”
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the new comedy from Mike Judge and Zach Woods, “In the Know”

title: Read the I.C.J. ruling
description: The International Court of Justice issued a preliminary ruling in a case accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.
content: The International Court of Justice issued a preliminary ruling in a case accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Supreme Court’s Decision Allowing an Alabama Execution to Proceed
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed the first American execution using nitrogen gas to move forward, with the court’s three liberal members publicly dissenting.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed the first American execution using nitrogen gas to move forward, with the court’s three liberal members publicly dissenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Rojanasakul
title: Panama Canal Drought Slows Cargo Traffic
description: The lake that allows the Panama Canal to function is at the lowest water level ever recorded for the start of the dry season.
content: The lake that allows the Panama Canal to function is at the lowest water level ever recorded for the start of the dry season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: 3.3%
description: The U.S. economy grew at a vigorous pace in the last three month of 2023, despite the high interest rates handed down by the Federal Reserve.
content: The U.S. economy grew at a vigorous pace in the last three month of 2023, despite the high interest rates handed down by the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan and Karen Hanley
title: The Biggest Surprises From the Oscar Nominations
description: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch. Here is our analysis of the biggest surprises and omissions.
content: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch. Here is our analysis of the biggest surprises and omissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso
title: U.N. Court Stops Short of Calling for Cease-Fire in Gaza
description: The International Court of Justice ordered Israel to take actions to prevent genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
content: The International Court of Justice ordered Israel to take actions to prevent genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times
